9.69.text:
- And we met on a mutual
friend from drama school

12.23.text: took us on a trip to New York

14.10.text: and we became really close friends.

20.99.text:
I came from a family, both
my parents were drug addicts

24.45.text: and so the first 16 years of my life

27.11.text:
were pretty intense and
there was just a lot.

30.99.text:
I never really knew
what to expect at home.

33.95.text: There was a lot of fear, anxiety.

36.19.text: On the outside it looked fine.

38.21.text: You know, we went to a good school,

40.33.text:
we were well turned
out we always had food,

43.63.text: but my parents were just never present

45.95.text: and were never really able to be reliable

48.53.text: and they were never able to come to

50.51.text: kind of anything related to, you know,

52.61.text: school productions, or anything like that.

54.61.text: So I had this big kind of part of me

57.21.text:
that just never really
felt like I was good enough

59.89.text:
and I excelled at school,
I got straight A's,

62.85.text: I had friends, I had boyfriends,

64.87.text:
and yet I still just
never felt good enough.

67.45.text:
And so, ironically, it
was actually when they

69.73.text: became sober when I was 16 that I went on

76.25.text: because I'd been so used to having drama

78.45.text:
and chaos at home, that was
what I was familiar with.

81.17.text:
So, yeah when they got
sober I just found myself,

84.83.text: that every relationship I was in,

86.43.text: I was cheating on boys, my boyfriends.

91.01.text:
I was drinking quite a
lot and then by the time

94.39.text: I got to drama center I met Joey

96.33.text: I'd started to get into cocaine.

98.45.text:
Nothing, it was never
extensive, it was just kind of,

102.46.text: it was a party, you know,

103.75.text:
I was always very an extrovert
and I socialized a lot.

107.31.text: But yeah I kind of really struggled.

Joey had a very different
upbringing to mine

but we found ourself in quite
a similar place didn't we?

much more stable actually.

My parents don't really
drink, don't use drugs,

there was no sort of obvious
addictive behavior at home

130.63.text: and yet I was just quite a naughty child

and I think a lot of
people might relate to,

149.60.text:

that aren't safe from young
age, dodgy things can happen,

and instead of dealing
with any of that stuff

159.97.text: I just sort of kept going.

161.51.text:

little bit more heavily

but we did have a common

and quite destructive

graduating from drama
school, had a big dream

198.47.text:
to, you know, do very well
in the acting industry.

206.16.text: from sort of the get go from graduation

and our two respective
best friends did very well,

and when I say very well
I mean kind of Hollywood,

and really successful

221.73.text: and so, looking out at them,

we just quickly went downhill

and we just sort of started

238.05.text:
where both of us realized and
sort of admitted to each other

Persia was more heavily
involved with drugs,

- And then there was a

256.65.text: where we both happened to end up going out

260.79.text:
yours was an alcoholic, mine

and they'd been much more

me, it was really painful

283.67.text: because he ended up cheating on me.

290.71.text: and I found that it was really just,

294.34.text:
it kind of, it was like
looking in the mirror

296.20.text: and suddenly I saw all these things

298.20.text:
that I had done and all
this behavior that before

300.78.text: I hadn't really thought about what that

303.75.text:
was doing to other people or
how other people would feel.

307.60.text:
And that relationship
took me to getting into

312.42.text:
a 12 step fellowship
which is called Al-Anon

314.16.text:
which is for friends and family

And I'd actually read
about that in this book

319.54.text: when I was away in Thailand with my dad

321.72.text:
and my dad had said, "I'm
really quite worried about you,"

324.86.text:
because I'd been doing drugs
and I'd been, you know,

329.80.text: having these crazy relationships with men

332.76.text: since we graduated from drama school,

334.90.text:
but I could keep all that
under wraps from my family

336.90.text: and as far as they knew, I was auditioning

343.74.text: and I put on two stone in two months

347.60.text: because I was eating so much crap,

349.76.text:
I was drinking beer,
I wasn't going to bed,

351.76.text:
I was getting on stage,
hadn't been to bed.

354.50.text:
It just felt awful and that I
couldn't hide from my parents.

358.16.text: I came back like two months later

359.92.text:
and they saw this kind of
sudden, massive weight gain.

364.24.text:
And so dad said, you know,
"oh let's go away to Thailand

367.18.text:
and just have a little
trip," and it was basically

369.30.text:
so he could talk to me and
just say what's going on?

371.77.text: I was given this book before I went

374.00.text:
and this book was all about
the daughters of addicts

377.34.text: and it said that the daughters of addicts

379.42.text:
tend to inherit a predisposition
to unhealthy relationships

382.96.text:
with men and possibly their
own addictions as well

385.84.text: and I thought, oh my God, this is me.

388.04.text: And my dad just said to me one morning,

389.93.text:
"You know, I've really
learned in my life,"

391.56.text:
and he was a drug addict at the
extreme end as was my mother

396.64.text: and they'd been in rehab and he said,

399.10.text:
"What I learned in rehab
is that if you focus

401.72.text:
on your insides the outsides
will take care of themself."

404.08.text:
And I think that really,
that's been the kind of mantra

410.48.text:
that our whole life
changed when we realized

413.94.text: that that is really true because

415.56.text: from that point on we thought,

417.14.text: I came back actually from that holiday

418.92.text:
and Joey just saw this
really big change in me

420.94.text:
and I just said I want to
start looking at my stuff.

423.50.text:
So I start going to
these Al-Anon meetings.

425.56.text: So, yeah, it was looking at my behavior,

428.56.text:
looking at what my childhood,
started having therapy,

432.16.text: and Joey went down kind of a similar path

434.56.text: in her own ways, well didn't you?

436.22.text:
- It was really inspiring
because we were living together

438.10.text:
and suddenly Persia comes
back, she's looking radiant.

440.64.text:
The 11 days or whatever
in Thailand with her dad

443.40.text: she'd been doing sort of lots of health.

445.48.text:
Just she looked great and she
was even just down to details

450.78.text:
she wasn't drinking as much,
she was eating healthy food

453.76.text:
and the whole thing was
just quite intriguing.

455.92.text:
We were living together so
I was like do you know what,

458.36.text: this is interesting, a lifestyle change.

460.78.text: And so we both, I would say at that point,

462.65.text: dipped our toe in the pool

464.70.text: of sort of making positive change.

467.50.text: And it was only really, months later,

one who had been through
rehab and the other,

480.09.text:
my boyfriend at the time who
was in AA and four years sober.

When we got dumped on the

was the moment that we
both were in a lot of pain

491.84.text: and went right, we can either go out

493.64.text: and do what we always do,

496.78.text: and sit with this and meet this pain

502.36.text:
that there's a different
way to process these things.

509.46.text: and the work that we now do today

511.12.text: because we spent the next few months

513.12.text:
going to 12 step therapy,
reading self-help books,

516.22.text: going to one to one therapy.

I gave up drinking at
that point in my life

524.16.text: That's four years old, I wish.

527.68.text:
And Persia dramatically
cut back on drinking

531.12.text: and is now a moderate drinker.

533.28.text: We both had kind of a stretch of time

536.02.text: away from any kind of romance.

538.12.text: It was just a real kind of healing period

540.78.text: which inspired us to set up what was

544.30.text: at the beginning just a very simple blog

548.92.text: really the intention was to kind of make

551.44.text:
the principles of self-help
and spirituality accessible

554.56.text: and aspirational to people our age,

557.38.text: cause we'd always seen it as quite naff

559.14.text: and a bit embarrassing and you know,

561.06.text: why would you want to help yourself?

562.34.text: The only people that ever get seen

564.00.text: reading self-help books are kind of

565.72.text:
middle aged women sobbing
in the self-help aisle.

567.82.text:
And we were like actually,
the ideas in these books

569.62.text: are really good but we want to package it

572.46.text: and help other people to understand

575.40.text:
how you can implement
the stuff in your life.

578.40.text: And that was what the blog started as.

580.36.text: What we were really inspired by

581.90.text:
is this idea of the 20's
are the launching pad

585.68.text: to the rest of your life.

586.78.text:
So the decisions you make
during that time frame

589.30.text: about career, who you choose to date,

591.86.text: the people you surround yourself by,

593.60.text: all of those things will have

594.92.text:
a knock on effect for
the rest of your life.

596.88.text: And so why not choose to set yourself up

600.22.text: as well as you possibly can?

602.30.text:
There's so many things
we can't control in life

604.02.text:
but actually we can make
some really healthy decisions

606.98.text:
which are gonna put us at
least on the right track.

609.68.text:
And so that's kind of where
it all came from as an idea.

613.50.text: - Well initially it literally just started

615.96.text: as a little blog as Joey mentioned.

we'd seen that the power

and in people being
honest, because by the time

you get to a 12 step meeting,

631.98.text:
and in that space you can

and be honest because

where we just share a

about what their needs are,

845.44.text: and we've not had someone yet

who we have not felt confident

and there are limitations

to what our services will be

So anyone who had a very

873.34.text: cause I think it's clear that

876.28.text: - What's happened with social media is now

878.70.text: there's healthy living which came over

kind of from America
and initially was quite

883.68.text: a positive thing, has now been warped

and it's kind of become

890.22.text:
to be perfect because teenage

894.20.text: are looking at pictures on YouTube

899.30.text:
beautiful girls on the beach

904.38.text: And they feel like they're never

907.29.text: gonna be able to live up to that.

909.18.text:
So there's this kind of

912.33.text: that's going on whereby you wake up

914.64.text:
and the first thing you
do, because let's face it,

916.80.text: we're all addicted to our iPhones.

918.18.text: They've become a way of life.

919.48.text:
The first thing we do in the

all this kind of consumerism

928.80.text:
and thoughts and it's
really, for young girls,

932.32.text:
I mean being a teenage

935.68.text: that we didn't actually get social media

941.06.text: - It seems like a lifetime now.

942.85.text: - It does seem like a lifetime ago.

But, yeah, these girls
who are getting it now

947.11.text: and they just feel like nothing

cases of the online bullying.

Children as young as nine

because they're being

because they're embarrassed

981.55.text:
- It's crazy how, I think

working with younger and

heart of Addictive Daughter

1143.69.text:
what our message is is it
comes down to self-worth.

1145.59.text: Every addictive behavior is a result

1148.05.text:
because you don't feel
good about who you are.

1149.93.text: You don't feel good about yourself.

1153.22.text: because we feel bad about ourselves

1154.57.text: and we feel bad about ourselves

1155.71.text:
because we're self-destructive
and it's such a vicious cycle

1157.93.text:
and it's all very well
stopping the addictive behavior

1160.55.text: and saying well I'm gonna stop drinking

1162.53.text:
or I'm gonna stop this
or I'm gonna stop that.

1164.25.text:
But if you don't actually
look at the reasons why

1165.97.text: you were doing that in the first place

1167.37.text: and that is the painful thing.

1168.73.text:
That is where therapy,
counseling, support groups

1171.78.text:
really come in because you
have to look underneath

1175.78.text: and really get to grips with why you were

1178.55.text:
doing that in the first
place and it's painful.

1181.57.text: As Joey said, when we first went through

1183.37.text:
this process ourselves it
was really, really difficult

1186.01.text:
and a lot of people just,
they don't want to do it.

1189.17.text: - Don't want to look at it.

1190.17.text:
But the journey inwards is
amazing and I think we can both,

1192.99.text:
obviously we have things
going on in our lives

1195.33.text: and we still struggle, but to be able to,

1197.81.text:
the book that we've
written, The Inner Fix,

1200.09.text: we have a line in it and we say you know,

1202.31.text: to us, living a sort of more spiritual

1204.63.text:
and connected life is just
about meeting your pain

1208.33.text:
with love rather than
running from it in fear.

1211.61.text: And that's something I think that

1213.05.text:
a few years ago we were both
doing quite a lot of running.

1215.67.text: If we felt rubbish about ourselves,

1219.87.text:
if we were feeling anxiety
which we did a lot,

1223.11.text:
and we still have days
where we struggle with it.

1225.49.text: But, we would run from it and we would go

1228.31.text: okay, how can I medicate this?

1232.19.text:
And these days we've got
healthier ways of dealing with it

1235.67.text:
and it's about sitting with
it and moving through it.

1238.07.text:
- We really just want
people to see that self-care

1241.11.text:
and looking at your
problems and your struggles

1245.93.text: and meeting them with healthier behaviors

1249.63.text:
is only gonna benefit you in
every single area of your life.

1252.89.text:

people around you too,

1254.79.text: because since we've worked on ourselves,

1259.93.text:
I mean, after all the
man problems we've had,

1269.61.text:
- That is huge and even

We definitely sort of
daily work to communicate.

We spend a lot of time
together cause we're friends

1285.83.text: and I think our wider friendships as well.

1293.22.text:
and making sure that

1298.83.text:
then everything externally,
like Persia's dad said,

I think what we've realized
is that there's so many

scale we would love to,
